application.ref: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

titleStmt.title: Painless Prognosis of Myasthenia Gravis using Machine Learning

analytic.title: Painless Prognosis of Myasthenia Gravis using Machine Learning

div.p: • Implement and compare machine learning algorithms to predict with high confidence, the presence of a chronic condition, Myasthenia Gravis which affect about 200,000 people in the US alone.

• We have trained our algorithms on 22 co-factors/features commonly found with Myasthenia Gravis, and could also predict the probability of being afflicted with Myasthenia Gravis given a patient history and a questionnaire.

div.head: What Are We Predicting? Myasthenia Gravis Diagnosis

div.p: Step a: Baseline Model, Logistic Regression

• The CNN model provided us with the highest F1 score, implying a good classifier model • We see that, Random Forests perform well too as a classifier • As CNN is a a good fit, this implies that some of the co-factors are better predictors than others

div.head: Discussion
div.p: • The model can be extended to predict the existence of other side effects of myasthenia gravis • To achieve better calibration, multiple algorithms can be used simultaneously
• Improving the quality of life would be the final goal to any life-sciences project

div.head: Future
div.p: • We have obtained the NIH patient dataset with 22 cofactors.
• Made possible by the contribution of Dr. Muppiddi at Stanford Neurosciences.
• We have 22 cofactors in the dataset to predict we trained our Algorithms on

div.head: What Training Data Do We Have? 12056 patient data
div.p: To ease the problem set above, we divided the problem into the following steps. In addition, we have divided the problem into sub problems: a) Transform the NIH dataset into metrics for the algorithms (Fig 2a). b) Prediction Diagnosis on a test-set with Logistic regression as baseline c) Use GDA, CNN's, Naïve Baye's and Random Forests and calculate F1 scores.

div.head: What Are We Predicting? Myasthenia Gravis Diagnosis
Step a: Baseline Model, Logistic Regression
div.p: • The CNN model provided us with the highest F1 score, implying a good classifier model • We see that, Random Forests perform well too as a classifier • As CNN is a a good fit, this implies that some of the co-factors are better predictors than others

div.head: Discussion
div.p: • The model can be extended to predict the existence of other side effects of myasthenia gravis • To achieve better calibration, multiple algorithms can be used simultaneously • Improving the quality of life would be the final goal to any life-sciences project

div.head: Future
div.p: • We have obtained the NIH patient dataset with 22 cofactors.
• Made possible by the contribution of Dr. Muppiddi at Stanford Neurosciences.
• We have 22 cofactors in the dataset to predict we trained our Algorithms on

div.head: What Training Data Do We Have? 12056 patient data
div.p: To ease the problem set above, we divided the problem into the following steps. In addition, we have divided the problem into sub problems: a) Transform the NIH dataset into metrics for the algorithms (Fig 2a). b) Prediction Diagnosis on a test-set with Logistic regression as baseline c) Use GDA, CNN's, Naïve Baye's and Random Forests and calculate F1 scores.

div.head: NIH dataset with parameters
div.p: Step a. Convert

div.head: De-noised Data
div.p: Step b. Baseline
Step b: GDA, Naïve Bayes, CNN • The obtained data-set contained scores and data which were not readily useable for training algorithms.

• We converted the raw data into trainable metrics for comparison. • We implemented GDA, Naïve Bayes, CNN using Keras, and Random Forests to obtain the recall and the F1 Scores Baseline F1 Score: 0.836

div.head: Comparison of Algorithms
div.p: We have used Logistic Regression as the baseline model as used in several other Medical Literature. This is convenient and gives us a baseline to compare the other algorithms. The data set was shuffled and split into 10000 data points for training and 2056 data points for the devset. We then compute the recalls, and the F-! Scores on the dev-set. The following is a summary of the results
Step c. Predictions F1 Scores

Age • Gender • BMI • Years diagnosed with MG • AcHR Antibodies • MuSK Antibodies • MuSK and AcHR present • Seronegative • Thymectomy • FSS is greater than 36 • Sleep Apnea • Non-Invasive Ventilation Support • NIV number • MG-QoL 15 • ESS • PSQI • FSS • MG-ADL • MG
